title: Alternative to Caslon that is more suited for the web?
content:
We had a new logo done for our organization. The designer decided to set our org's name in Caslon all-caps. Aesthetically, I don't like it, but I'm at the point where I'm just happy to have a logo that the comittee approved so we can start using it.

That said, aesthetic preferences aside, the face just isn't suited for use online. When reduced to a suitable size for our site's banner, the contrast between thins and thicks become distracting as the thin strokes begin to dissappear.

I've suggested some alternatives (they seem to like Minion Small Caps) but the designer is insistent on Caslon.

Can anyone suggest a Caslon-ish face that isn't quite as extreme on the thin strokes?
author: aluminum

comments.content:
There are authentic size-specific masters  
of Caslon done by the late Justin Howes:

[http://www.hwcaslon.com/](http://web.archive.org/web/20150219021735/http:/www.hwcaslon.com/ "http://www.hwcaslon.com/")

hhp

Which Caslon are you using? Adobe's has a semibold.

There are a number of related faces that might work, [Freight Text](http://web.archive.org/web/20150219021735/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/garagefonts/freight-text/) comes to mind.

No, not Freight=Caslon, but not kidding either.

See [this](http://web.archive.org/web/20150219021735/http:/www.joshuadarden.com/shop/fbig_notes.php) for where I got the idea.

I think a single all caps word set in Freight _might_ pass at the smaller onscreen size that "aluminum" is looking for— depending on the word, of course. Compare:  
 [Freight text](http://web.archive.org/web/20150219021735/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/garagefonts/freight-text/book/testdrive.html?s=CASLON&p=16)  
and  
 [New Caslon.](http://web.archive.org/web/20150219021735/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/ef/new-caslon-b/roman/testdrive.html?s=CASLON&p=16)

I guess Freight _would_ be too far afield.

You might look at [Scangraphic's Caslon SB.](http://web.archive.org/web/20150219021735/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/efscangraphic/caslon-sb/regular/testdrive.html?s=CASLON&p=16) It seems to be pretty sturdy.

If you are only using it as a one time application like a name in a banner I would suggest having one of these type designers draw a web version of the name. Other than that set it in illustrator and add a very thin stroke to the letters. Not a good solution but its not like its a 300dpi enviroment.
